title: 107_hr2645
content: The "Motor Donor Act" establishes a National Organ Donor Registry under the Public Health Service Act. The purpose of this subpart is to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, improve information on donation, ensure accurate information on individual wishes, and provide grants to states for donor registries through driver's license applications. The term "motor vehicle driver's license" refers to any ID issued by a state motor vehicle authority. The Secretary will establish a national organ and tissue donor registry, containing information of individuals who wish to be donors. The registry will include personal details and a unique identification number. Coordination will be done with states and organ procurement organizations. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry with personal details and a unique identification number. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations to share data and promote registry establishment. The Motor Donor Act requires the Secretary to coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations to establish organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations will have 24-hour access to the Registry using a password assigned by the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary must disseminate information to all U.S. citizens residing in the country within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Motor Donor Act mandates the dissemination of information about organ and tissue donations to U.S. citizens through a website. Participation in the Registry does not impact organ allocation. The Motor Donor Act requires information about organ and tissue donations to be shared on a website. Participation in the Registry does not affect organ allocation and serves as an individual's intent to donate, with the option to cancel at any time. The Secretary notifies individuals of their right to cancel participation in the Registry. Grants are awarded to States for implementing State registries linked to the motor vehicle driver's license application process. States must submit applications to the Secretary for grant consideration. Each State seeking a grant for organ and tissue donation programs must submit an application to the Secretary, demonstrating procedures for individuals to make legally binding gifts through driver's license applications. The application must assure compliance with specific requirements. The State procedures for organ and tissue donation programs must include a process in driver's license applications for individuals to designate their intent to be donors. The application must also ask if the individual wishes to have their donor designation in the State registry. The State procedures for organ and tissue donation programs require driver's license applications to include a question about donor designation in the State registry or on the driver's license for those who answer affirmatively. The State procedures for organ donation programs require individuals to indicate their donor preference on their driver's license or in the State registry. Information must be forwarded to the Registry within 100 days of designation, including any changes in designation or address. Individuals who choose not to be organ donors must also be noted in the State procedures. The State procedures for organ donation programs require individuals to indicate their donor preference on their driver's license or in the State registry. Information regarding affirmative responses must be recorded in the individual's computer record for 24-hour access by organ procurement organizations without any fees. Individuals who choose not to be organ donors will not have their information forwarded to the Registry. The State agency provides 24-hour access to donor information to organ procurement organizations without fees. Priority in grant awards is given to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a State cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, is established. The advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, known as the `Task Force', consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ or tissue donations, organ procurement, or organ transplants. At least 1 member must be a physician with experience in performing organ transplants, and another member must have experience in organ procurement. The Task Force consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ or tissue donations, procurement, or transplants. At least 1 member must be a physician with experience in performing organ transplants, and another member must have experience in organ procurement. Members serve a 3-year term, with staggered terms for initial members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force's functions include offering partnerships. The Task Force, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, serves a 3-year term with staggered terms for initial members. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force's functions include offering partnerships with the Coalition on Donation and conducting a study to improve the Registry and increase public awareness about organ and tissue donation. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, conducts a study to improve the Registry, increase public awareness about organ and tissue donation, and enhance the donation process. Task Force members receive travel expenses but no compensation for their services. The Task Force, appointed by the Secretary, may accept voluntary and uncompensated services of its members. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted. Health and Human Services will provide administrative support to the Task Force. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. "Subpart 2--Organ Procurement. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE." Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the purpose of contacting individuals regarding the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
